author: jgm
content:
There's short-term and long-term.

Short-term, if we have lots of validators active then they _may_ be able to finalize before too many of them are slashed (but then the chain will stop finalizing again).  If they aren't active then they will leak out over the next 3 weeks until they start to exit.

Long-term, we need the validators who have double-voted out of the chain before we can finalize consistently.  Either slashed or leaked, but again we're talking weeks until we have a stable validator set.

author: potuz
content:
Sure, 
- Nodes run more smoothly when there are blocks in the chain, when a block is not there we start hitting cache misses and need to start applying heuristics because the block may have been there and we didn't see it>
- The chain can pack more attestations when there are more blocks in the chain and thus be less forked.
- Syncing nodes receive more regular updates of their status when there are more blocks in the chain
- Because of the above we get to sync more nodes, the more nodes we sync the faster the remaining nodes will sync

I hope the above is enough to justify we that we need blocks in the canonical chain, not just to have a canonical chain. So in order to achieve blocks:
- Validators need to propose
- Validators need to not attest because if they attest they get slashed and then we lose those validators' block proposals

In addition:
- Slashings stress nodes making syncing harder for everyone
- Stressed nodes create forks because they build on top of earlier heads. 
- Forks lead to less stability on the chain. 

So in short: we want blocks, we don't want slashings, we need validators in the good chain. 

Finalization will come once we have everyone synced.

author: ralexstokes
content: the "get back to finality" regime should be "monotonic"

author: ralexstokes
content: we need 2/3 of the v-set to finalize -- to get there on holesky at the moment, we need to exit a large chunk of the v-set, as they currently cannot attest without being slashed (assuming someone is running a slasher somewhere, and we have reason to believe it is)

author: ralexstokes
content: so to get to finality again, we just have to let the chain process all of the exits, and then eventually the distribution will rebalance

author: fradamt
content: Note that slashed-but-not-exited validators still count in the total active balance, which defines the 2/3 quorum

author: fradamt
content: Even if you slashed everyone, you still have to wait for them to exit before resuming finality
